question_details.title: Will Greece remain a highly developed liberal democracy in 2035?
question_details.description:
This question assesses Greece's status as a developed, liberal democracy through two key lenses: human development and the health of its democratic institutions.

Human Development Index (HDI): This UN index is a summary measure of average achievement in key dimensions of human development: health, education, and standards of living. The HDI combines statistics on life expectancy, mean and expected years of schooling, and Gross National Income (GNI) per capita to rank countries into four tiers of human development. As of the 2025 report (with data for 2023), Greece's HDI score is 0.908, ranking it 34th and placing it firmly in the ‘very high human development’ category.

Liberal Democracy Index (LDI): This V-Dem Institute index measures the quality of a country’s democratic institutions. For the data year 2024, Greece's LDI score is 0.58, ranking 49th of 179. The LDI is constructed by combining two major indices: the Electoral Democracy Index (measuring free elections and freedoms of expression and association) and the Liberal Component Index (measuring checks on the executive and protections for individual liberties).

Greece's democratic foundation is rooted in its post-junta transition and membership in the European Union. However, its democratic quality has recently eroded. The V-Dem Institute's 2025 Democracy Report now registers Greece as a "statistically confirmed autocratizer" whose democratic decline is "steep". This process of autocratization began in 2019 and has been characterized by a gradual weakening of the rule of law and attacks on media freedom. A 2022 government wiretapping scandal targeting opposition leaders and journalists drew significant concern. Consequently, Greece lost its long-held status as a "liberal democracy" in 2023, and is now classified as an "electoral democracy". This question asks whether Greece will successfully reverse this democratic backsliding and navigate its challenges to meet the criteria for a highly developed, liberal democratic nation, defined by clear HDI and LDI thresholds.
question_details.resolution_criteria:
This question will resolve as Yes if both of the following conditions are met for the calendar year 2034. If either or both conditions are not met, it will resolve as No.

Human Development Index (HDI): According to the first official publication of the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) Human Development Report that includes data for the year 2034, Greece must be placed in the top 50 list of high human development countries.

Liberal Democracy Index (LDI): According to the V-Dem Institute's dataset released in 2035 (containing data for the year 2034), Greece's score on the Liberal Democracy Index must be 0.500 or higher.

Across 12 expert forecasts covering public policy, international relations, political science, economics, and European studies, there is near-consensus that Greece will almost certainly remain a highly developed country (meeting the HDI top-50 threshold). The real uncertainty revolves around whether Greece will recover enough from recent democratic backsliding to again qualify as a 'liberal democracy' with an LDI of 0.5 or higher in 2034. Experts consistently identify Greece’s EU membership, economic recovery, and history of resilience as key positives, citing strong institutional anchoring, robust economic fundamentals, and significant pressure/incentives from the EU to uphold democratic norms. However, nearly all note that once democratic backsliding is statistically confirmed (as with V-Dem for Greece), base rates suggest that full recovery of liberal democracy within a decade is rare and difficult, typically requiring a combination of major reforms, elite consensus, or potent shocks.

Negative drivers include persistent corruption, political fragmentation, media freedom restrictions, and the normalization of executive aggrandizement. The trend of global democratic erosion, regional security pressures (such as with Turkey), and structural challenges (youth unemployment, over-reliance on tourism) are also cited as risks that could perpetuate or deepen democratic stagnation. Several experts specifically reference recent EU struggles to reverse backsliding in members like Hungary and Poland.

Probabilities assigned by the forecasters for a 'Yes' outcome range from 35% to 73%, with a moderate central tendency. Those with the lowest probabilities (35–45%) emphasize the difficulty and slowness of reversing autocratization, even with EU membership and domestic activism, while those above 60% are cautiously optimistic, believing ongoing modernization, civil society mobilization, and gradual reforms will suffice for meeting the LDI threshold. The modal (most common) band is 38–45% (five forecasts), followed by a cluster of moderate to optimistic probabilities (55–73%).

The leading scenario for a 'No' outcome is that Greece maintains very high human development but fails to restore key liberal-democratic institutions; ongoing institutional erosion, incomplete reforms, or a failure of EU/democratic conditionality could keep LDI below 0.5 despite continued economic growth. The prevailing 'Yes' scenario involves renewed institutional reform—possibly catalyzed by EU pressure, civil society, or political turnover—restoring judicial independence, media freedom, and checks on executive power, with economic resilience ensuring continued high HDI.

In sum, the expert community sees Greece's HDI status as highly secure but is divided on the likelihood of democratic recovery in line with liberal thresholds by 2035, with a cautiously pessimistic mean forecast and risk weighted to the democratic dimension rather than the developmental one.
